## Git {#git-resources}

[Git-it](https://github.com/jlord/git-it-electron) is a Desktop App for Learning Git and GitHub. Downloads for [Mac](https://github.com/jlord/git-it-electron/releases/download/4.3.0/Git-it-Mac-x64.zip), [Windows](https://github.com/jlord/git-it-electron/releases/download/4.3.0/Git-it-Win-ia32.zip), and [Linux](https://github.com/jlord/git-it-electron/releases/download/4.3.0/Git-it-Linux-x64.zip). 

[Flight rules for Git](https://github.com/k88hudson/git-flight-rules#flight-rules-for-git) is a cookbook-style resource for Git documentation. 

## R {#r-resources}

[Introduction to R](https://www.datacamp.com/courses/free-introduction-to-r) is an interactive R programming tutorial provided by DataCamp. This particular DataCamp course is free and is a great place to get started if you are a complete beginner to programming in R. It will take around 4 hours to complete the full course and you will need to sign up for a free DataCamp account to get started. 

[R for Data Science](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/) is an online textbook which introduces the 'tidyverse' approach to R programming that is now widely adopted by the community. It is co-authored by Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham, two very well-known and well-respected R developers. 

[Text Mining with R](https://www.tidytextmining.com/) is an online textbook which focuses on strategies for text mining and general text analysis. 


## RStudio {#rstudio-resources}

[Getting started with R and RStudio](https://francojc.github.io/2017/08/14/getting-started-with-r-and-rstudio/) is a blog entry Jerid Francom wrote that covers getting R and RStudio installed and getting acquainted with how R and RStudio work together to facilitate and organize research projects.
